ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned how to properly form an argument and follow a cohesiv method for essay building while having an opportunity to learn from and work alongside my peers for constructive feedback.
Research methods, presenting, writing and revision. Really forces you to think critically about the research you're doing.
Course to support the yearlong thesis in the PLSC major. Included regular updates, literature reviews, and discussion with classmates about our research process and its challenges/progression.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I really liked that this course gave us the opportunity to bounce ideas off of our classmates and get feedback and suggestions from our peers. Sometimes it felt like some more structure would've helped the course.

Strength - I enjoyed Professor Hierro's guidance and support throughout the semester
Weakness - I would have liked a more structured outline to support my time management skills around how to prepare to write the essay

The best thing about this class was how it forced me to stay on track with my senior thesis. The assignments weren't always the most useful thing I could be doing for my thesis at that time, but the fact that they existed made sure that I did them when I might otherwise have kept putting things off.

Strenghts: I made great progress on my thesis and received consistently helpful feedback.

Weaknesses: You have to check Canvas regularly for updates on readings, presentations, peer reviews, etc. Updates are not regular.

I think much of this course would be more beneficial in the latter half of the thesis writing process. I felt like I was frequently under pressure to write pages and turn in assignments when I would have appreciated more time to take stock of the research in the field and work with that. For example, in the first month or two of the course, we were expected to turn in an annotated bibliography -- this felt like a waste of time, and by the end of the semester I had moved past the sources I used in the bib. The course could be improved by being more understanding of different research processes, or maybe having a bi-weekly course all year instead of a weekly course in one semester.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course because it's a great opportunity to dive deep into your senior essay topic.

Yes, if they are a PLSC student intending to take the year long senior essay. Professor Hierro is incredibly warm and supporting through the process and cares a lot about your individual growth and success as a student with your essay. She is very engaging and also does a lot of work to help find sources for her students which is always appreciated.
If you want to have a set-up for a polished thesis in your second semester, yes.

If you have a solid relationship with your thesis advisor and regularly meet with them, I would not recommend this course (some of the students in the course were technically enrolled but did not attend). This course felt extraneous and created unneccessary work that I will not end up using in my final thesis, and my meetings with my thesis advisor were much more productive. If you need frequent deadlines and do not have a hands-on thesis advisor, this might be the course for you.
